results.title: The Cabin in the cotton
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, First National Pictures and Michael Curtiz
results.brief_description: A tenant share-cropper is befriended by a southern plantation owner. He finds himself torn between loyalty to his class and an obligation to their enemy who is also his benefactor. Cast includes Richard Barthelmess, Dorothy Jordan, Bette Davis, hardie Albright, David Landau. Based on the novel by Harry Harrison Kroll.

results.title: The Cabbage butterfly
results.brief_description: The life cycle of the cabbage butterfly is shown. The adult lays the eggs on the underside of the cabbage leaf, the eggs hatch and progress through five larval stages. Time-lapse photography follows the emergence of the butterfly from the chrysalis. Suggests methods of keeping the various stages in observance jars. English commentary, captions in Japanese. Credits in Japanese.

results.title: The Byzantine Empire [B&W]
results.brief_description: The Byzantine Empire had become, by 750 AD, the richest and most powerful in the world. This film presents a brief historical outline of the Empire, and indicates its important cultural contributions in art, religion and scholarship. Photographed principally in Greece and Turkey, the film captures the richness of the mosaic works, icons and architecture. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Buzz of rock and roll
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Dale Lynch
results.brief_description: Documentary about three Australian musicians who are also tinnitus sufferers- Fiona Horne (DefFX), Rod Ling (July Fourteenth) and Richard Pleasance (Boom Crash Opera). Tinnitus is a condition that causes ringing in the ears and affects one in five people.

results.title: The Butterfly ball and the grasshopper's feast
results.creator_credit: Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films, Jack King and Lee Mishkin
results.brief_description: This delightful Halas and Batchelor cartoon has a number of well-known rock stars singing an infectious song while the visuals enact the story of a frog and his friends who join together to attend the most spectacular ball of the year. Based on part of the book of verses and illustrations, “Butterfly Ball” by Alan Aldridge and William Plomer. Music by Roger Glover and animation by Harold Whitaker. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: The Butcher boy
results.creator_credit: Geffen Pictures, Redmond Morris, Stephen Woolley and Neil Jordan
results.brief_description: The voice of an adult Francie O’Grady reflects back on his youth. There were three things important to young Francie; his long suffering but mentally unstable mother, his alcoholic Da (Stephen Rea) - “the best music man that ever lived, and his best friend, Joe (Alan Boyle). Francie, clearly the leader in his friendship with blood brother Joe, centers the pair in a fantastic world removed from the reality of their everyday existence in a small Irish town. Set against the backdrop of the Cold War and the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis, Communism is as much a contributing factor to Francie’s cynicism towards the world as are aliens, and Mrs Nugent, mother of the young boy who threatens to be “better” friends with Joe. Inhabiting Francie’s fantasy world is Our Lady, controversially portrayed by Sinead O’Connor, who speaks to Francie in times of need. Francie and Joe live in a world influenced by popular culture and their rural environment. Thus, their days are marked by comics, flash bars, fishing, and American films. Francie’s questionable antics land him in a boys home, and the nature of these antics, as they are transferred stylistically into stagey cartoonish sets, render the scenes with a disturbing, puzzling and cruel aura. When Francie returns to the village he is outraged to find that a lot has changed. He begins a job assisting a local butcher who slaughters pigs, earning him the eponymous title, Butcher Boy. Pigs are a central theme throughout the film, and one which inspires the final disturbing scenes. Cast includes Stephen Rea, Fiona Shaw and Eamonn Owens (Francie). Adapted from the book by Patrick McCabe.

results.title: The Butcher = Le Boucher
results.creator_credit: Les Films La Boetie, Euro International, Andre Genoves and Claude Chabrol
results.brief_description: A tragic beauty and the beast love story set in a French village with a schoolmistress, a loner, finding herself drawn to an ex-army butcher she suspects of being a child-murderer. This ‘human beast’ is viewed with sympathy - he is deeply aware of the destructiveness within him. Helene is unable to give Popaul the love that he requires if the beast is to be cured. The controlled grace and fluency of Chabrol’s mise-en-scene concentrates everything on the relationship set in an autumnal provincial atmosphere. Cast includes Stephane Audran, Jean Yanne and Antonio Passalia. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: The Busy harbour
results.brief_description: Ted and Maria visit a tugboat captain in the busy harbour. He explains some of the many activities going on in the harbour; fishing boats unloading, tugboats pulling barges, cargo ships, a lighthouse and buoy. They take a ride on the captain’s tugboat.

results.title: The Business plan
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Geoffrey Barnes and Paul Humfress
results.brief_description: To succeed in an ever-increasing technologically oriented world, a business plan is needed. This provides the parameters for basic planning and acts as a stimulant for the viewer to ask the right questions and seek the right answers in an authentic business environment. It is of particular interest to owner/managers of small manufacturing businesses.
